original_title: Sri Lanka govt to revise fuel prices, increase fuel quota from June
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The Sri Lankan government will increase fuel quota with the price revision in the month of June, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said.
“Fuel Quota currently allowed on the National Fuel Pass QR system will be increased from the next month’s fuel price revision,” Wijesekera said in a twitter message.
“The decision was taken at the meeting held yesterday afternoon with the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation finance, commercial & marketing divisions.”
The fuel quota was increase in April ahead of the Sinhala and Tamil New year holidays as well, as the country had enough fuel stocks.
Sri Lanka introduced the quota system in August last year to limit the fuel consumption as it ran out of petrol and diesel due to foreign currency shortage.

The government declaration of sovereign debt default also deprived the state-run fuel retailer Ceypetco of receiving fuel on credit as many foreign banks refused to open corresponding Letter of Credit.
However, the government had been expecting the tight situation to ease after the International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved a $3 billion loan last month.
The global fuel prices have dropped, with WTI standing at 71.75 and Brent Crude standing at 76.41.

The Sri Lanka Rupee has appreciated against the US Dollar today, as per the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, accordingly, today’s buying rate of USD is Rs. 295.62 while the selling rate is Rs. 308.54.  (Colombo/May 26/2023)
